Chat with an OpenAI model

Source: R/provider-openai.R
chat_openai.Rd

OpenAI provides a number of chat-based models, mostly under the ChatGPT brand. Note that a ChatGPT Plus membership does not grant access to the API. You will need to sign up for a developer account (and pay for it) at the developer platform.

For authentication, we recommend saving your API key to the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable in your .Renviron file. You can easily edit this file by calling usethis::edit_r_environ().

Usage

chat_openai(
  system_prompt = NULL,
  turns = NULL,
  base_url = "https://api.openai.com/v1",
  api_key = openai_key(),
  model = NULL,
  seed = NULL,
  api_args = list(),
  echo = c("none", "text", "all")
)

Arguments

system_prompt

A system prompt to set the behavior of the assistant.

turns

A list of Turns to start the chat with (i.e., continuing a previous conversation). If not provided, the conversation begins from scratch.

base_url

The base URL to the endpoint; the default uses OpenAI.

api_key

The API key to use for authentication. You generally should not supply this directly, but instead set the OPENAI_API_KEY environment variable.

model

The model to use for the chat. The default, NULL, will pick a reasonable default, and tell you about. We strongly recommend explicitly choosing a model for all but the most casual use.

seed

Optional integer seed that ChatGPT uses to try and make output more reproducible.

api_args

Named list of arbitrary extra arguments appended to the body of every chat API call.

echo

One of the following options:

  • none: don't emit any output (default when running in a function).

  • text: echo text output as it streams in (default when running at the console).

  • all: echo all input and output.

Note this only affects the chat() method.

Value

A Chat object.

See also

Other chatbots: chat_bedrock(), chat_claude(), chat_cortex(), chat_databricks(), chat_gemini(), chat_github(), chat_groq(), chat_ollama(), chat_perplexity()

Examples

chat <- chat_openai()
#> Using model = "gpt-4o".
chat$chat("
  What is the difference between a tibble and a data frame?
  Answer with a bulleted list
")
#> - **Print Format**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Provides a more concise and readable print format by 
#> showing the first 10 rows and only the columns that fit on screen. It 
#> also shows the data type of each column below the column names.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Displays all rows and columns, which can result in 
#> overwhelming output for larger datasets.
#> 
#> - **Column Types**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Offers enhanced capabilities for handling different types
#> of data. Columns can include lists or complex objects, not just vectors.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Primarily consists of vectors, and each column must 
#> contain the same type of data, though factors are also supported 
#> inherently.
#> 
#> - **Subsetting Behavior**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Maintains a modern subsetting approach where single 
#> columns remain as tibbles unless explicitly requested as a vector using 
#> `[[` or `$`.
#>   - **Data Frame**: When extracting a single column using `[`, it results
#> in a data frame; extracting with `[[` returns a vector.
#> 
#> - **Handling Non-Standard Variable Names**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Does not automatically convert non-standard variable 
#> names (like those with spaces or special characters) into syntactically 
#> valid names, allowing more flexible column names.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Converts non-standard variable names into valid names
#> unless `check.names = FALSE` is specified.
#> 
#> - **Performance**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Offers better performance and integrates more seamlessly 
#> with tidyverse packages, providing enhanced functionality for data 
#> wrangling.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Suffices for basic data manipulation outside of the 
#> tidyverse but usually lacks the additional functionalities of tibbles.
#> 
#> - **Creation with Code**:  
#>   - **Tibble**: Can be created using the `tibble()` function, allowing 
#> control over column data types and preventing unintentionally creating 
#> factors, as it does not treat strings as factors by default.
#>   - **Data Frame**: Created using `data.frame()`, with strings being 
#> converted to factors by default, unless prevented with `stringsAsFactors 
#> = FALSE`.
#> 
#> Overall, tibbles are an evolution of data frames within the tidyverse 
#> ecosystem, aimed at providing a more user-friendly and powerful tool for 
#> data manipulation.
